head.title: One Good Turn Is Likely to Lead to Another

hedline.hl1: One Good Turn Is Likely to Lead to Another

abstract.p: Photos of 13-acre maze created by Allen Cockerline in his cornfield in Falls Village, Conn (M)

block.p: WHAT had been 13 acres of corn to feed a small herd of cattle has became a labyrinthine affair for those seeking a navigational challenge and willing to pay a $5 entry fee for it.

''Other farmers probably thought I'd gone off the deep,'' said Allen Cockerline, who created the maze in his Falls Village cornfield, ''but I thought it would be fun and a way to make the crop pay back while it's still in the ground.''

''Other farmers probably thought I'd gone off the deep,'' said Allen Cockerline, who created the maze in his Falls Village cornfield, ''but I thought it would be fun and a way to make the crop pay back while it's still in the ground.''
The challenge of the maze is to locate the patches of other crops -- sorghum, winter rye, sunflowers, and oats -- that Mr. Cockerline has planted within.
The maze, at the juncture of Routes 7 and 112, is open on weekends from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. through the end of the month.
